Date:  Wed, 01 Jan 2014 19:30:21 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Dec 31st.)
Hi all,

Here is Lovejoy captured yesterday. It seems a bit less active lacking in the nice tail structure of past days. Negative view shows the faint curving diffuse dust tail and narrow ion tail nicely.

LRGB: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2013_12_31dp.jpg

Negative: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2013_12_31neg_dp.jpg

106mm F5. STL-11k. LRGB. L: 5x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Date:  Fri, 03 Jan 2014 18:19:49 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Jan 3rd, 2014.)
Hi all,

Here is Comet Lovejoy captured earlier today. Looks as though a disconnection event may have occured in the tail. This a long exposure B filter image to help enhance the ion tail contrast.

Image: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2014_01_03dp.jpg

Neg: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2014_01_03neg_dp.jpg

106mm F5. STL-11k. Blue filter. 7x 3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Sun, 05 Jan 2014 16:55:19 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Jager 290P last night
Greetings comet imaging friends!

Here is another quite deep exposure on the 11th magnitude Comet Jager, now well placed in Auriga in the evening sky. This image is with my 12.5" f/5 newtonian, Lumicon coma corrector and I used 3 min subs guided on a faint nearby star to keep the comets motion under control for the final summed image. This is an LRGB, and a single set of RGB data was used to color all the star trails, and comet which appears slightly tawny here from no doubt dust.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/jager010414.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Tue, 07 Jan 2014 21:55:38 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Jan 7th, 2014.)
Hi all,

Here is C/2013 R1 obtained earlier today. Its really sporting quite distinctly separate dust and ion tails now, both notably different in colour.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2014_01_07dp.jpg

106mm F5. STL11k. LRGB. L: 6x3mins. RGB: 1x3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Thu, 16 Jan 2014 19:37:46 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2012 X1 (Jan 11th, 2014.)
Hi all,

Here is an image of C/2012 X1 (LINEAR) from Jan 11th. Its around 9th magnitude and looks quite different compared to its dramatic outburst back in October last year.

Jan 11th: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_x1_2014_01_11dp.jpg

Oct 2013: http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_x1_2013_11_06dp.jpg

17"CDK with FLI-PL6303E. LRGB. L: 5x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk

Date:  Fri, 17 Jan 2014 01:08:59 -0800
From:  zeroy99@gmail.com
Subject:  Re: Comet C/2012 X1 (Jan 11th, 2014.)
Presumably Damian uses a composite method where Stars are stacked separately from Comet stack then added together. I too would like to get more details as to how it's done but I know its complex. 
Date:  Fri, 17 Jan 2014 11:33:11 +0100
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Re: Comet C/2012 X1 (Jan 11th, 2014.)
a good tool is deepskystacker, there you can separately stck on images and comet, and after that the software combines the images. Unrotunately, it works not always perfect.
another good discription is: http://www.astrophoton.com/tips/comet_images.pdf
but you must have some skills in Photoshop with layers.

hope this give some direction...

__________________________________

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck

Brixiis Observatory (B96) - Kruibeke - Belgium
http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/
__________________________________
http://cara.uai.it - Cometary Archive for Af(Rho)
http://www.vvs.be - Belgian Association for Amateur Astronomers

Date:  Fri, 17 Jan 2014 18:24:39 +0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  BAA COMET TALE PUBLISHED
Hello all,
Jon Shanklin has announced the publication of the latest edition of the BAA Comet Section Journal. It is available at the following link:

http://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/~jds/tail33.pdf

Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section
British Astronomical Association

On Jan 17, 2014, at 11:24 AM, denis buczynski wrote:

Hello all,
>Jon Shanklin has announced the publication of the latest edition of the BAA Comet Section Journal. It is available at the following link:
>
>http://www.ast.cam.ac.uk/~jds/tail33.pdf

Date:  Sat, 18 Jan 2014 12:22:07 +0000
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] BAA COMET TALE PUBLISHED
Hi Chris,

I am glad you enjoyed the latest edition of The Comet Tale. There are PDF versions of back issues back to 1999. You can access these by going to
the BAA Comet section website at the following link::
www.ast.cam.ac.uk/~jds/
Once you have got the opening page up then you will see that the first item is the list of comet discoveries. Under that you will see a horizontal
list of highlighted links, click on publications and this will take you
to the links to the PDF's.
Best wishes
DenisBAA Comet Section

Date:  Thu, 23 Jan 2014 17:37:35 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2012 X1 with NGC 6384  (Jan 23rd, 2014.)
Hi all,

Here is C/2012 X1 alongside spiral galaxy NGC 6384. I had hoped to shoot this yesterday when they were much closer together but it was cloudy. Better luck today although they are further apart. Conditions were still not ideal though with  Interference from high clouds and moonlight.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_x1_2014_01_23dp.jpg

106mm F5 with STL-11k. LRGB. L: 25mins. RGB: 5mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************
Date:  Thu, 23 Jan 2014 10:50:55 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet C/2012 X1 with NGC 6384  (Jan 23rd, 2014.)
Excellent pairing! You can almost make out spiral arms in that tiny galaxy. Nice Job Damian...

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Alfons Diepvens 
Date:  Sun, 26 Jan 2014 18:51:40 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comets Lovejoy and Linear X1 - Finally over the observatorys east wall...
Greetings All,

It has been over a month that we have not been able to image these comet because they have been very low in the eastern morning twilight, but this morning we were able to get after the long wait at least a half an hour of clear aperture of comet Lovejoy before morning twilight. Fortunately, with the 12 inch, half the aperture occulted by the eastern walls rails still gives a very nice image of the comet, and as it rose it of course got brighter as the tube cleared the obstruction.

Processing this image was a bit challenging (thats why deep sky imagers fear shooting comets!) A single RGB set was taken of the star field. Next I pasted 8 copies of this onto the L channel data and moved the stars over the paths of the trailed stars. By combinging with lighten, the stars get colorized properly and I found that magazines really love the colored star streaks in comet shots. :) A separate image was used to colorize the moving comets head and brighter parts of its tail.

I did a last ditch effort to capture LInear X1 as well. As explained in the text on the web page below, the digital setting circles kept putting me about a degree off and it took me 15 minutes to find this darn comet. By then the sky was very blue and very bright. A quick 1 min exposures then the auto guider stopped tracking from too bright a sky. Sigh. Next time I start with Linear X1 first...

Here is the images, I hope you enjoy them as much as I did taking them:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/LovejoyLinearx1-012614.html

BTW, both me and Damian have comet images in the latest Astronomy Magazine.

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Mon, 27 Jan 2014 04:48:25 +0100

Date:  Mon, 03 Feb 2014 01:41:41 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Siding Spring with galaxy group (Feb 2nd, 2014.)
Hi all,

Here is C/2013 A1 (Siding Spring) captured on Feb 2nd alongside a compact group of remote galaxies in Fornax. The comet is still around 14th magnitude but a short dust tail is well seen.

For comparison the comet was around 30 light minutes away at the time of the image, while the distance to the group of galaxies in the image is around 500 million light years.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_a1_2014_02_02dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI CCD camera. LRGB. L: 30mins. RGB: 5mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

From:  John 
Subject:  Lovejoy C 2013 R1
Hi,

The comet is still quite bright and is easy to spot through my 60mm finder under dark sky. This 7x2 minutes exposure is through a 16 inch Newtonian at f4.5. The field of view is 29.4' x 44.6' arc minutes.

http://stardustobservatory.org/upload/comets/LovejoyC2013R1Feb620142035UTN16f45D7000iso64007x2min-Nassr_20140206170826.jpg

John

Date:  Fri, 07 Feb 2014 18:30:53 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Remote globular Arp-Madore 1 (Feb 6th.)
Hi all,

Here is a colour image obtained of the most remote globular cluster bound to the Milky way galaxy. It is located 400,000 l.y. away in the obscure constellation of Horologium. Its combined brightness of magnitude 16 makes this a very challenging object. It wasn't identified as a globular cluster until 1979. It is twenty five times further away from us than Omega Centauri.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/AM1_2014_02_06dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI-PL6303E. LRGB. L: 1hr. RGB: 10mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Luc 
Date:  Sat, 08 Feb 2014 21:27:54 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Two comets pass each other (Feb 8th, 2014.)
Hi all,

Here is C/2013 R1 and C/2012 X1 within the same field. They are presently moving apart fairly quickly and the last few days they have been at their closest. Luckily the weather finally cooperated to catch them together.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_x1_2014_02_08dp.jpg

106mm F5 with STL-11k camera. 2 frame mosaic. LRGB. L: 20mins. RGB: 3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

From:  Paul Mortfield 
Subject:  Comet Pairing
Collaborating with Sandy Barnes, we grabbed this pair of Lovejoy and LINEAR
on Feb 5 with his FSQ/STL11K combo.

http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/Lovejoy-Linear_20140205d.jpg

http://www.backyardastronomer.com/comets/Lovejoy-Linear_20140205d_inv.jpg

thanks for looking.

.paul.

Subject:  Observation of comets

Good morning.

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Feb 12th, 2014.)
Hi all,

Here is C/2013 R1 from Feb 12th. Looking rather less dramatic that it did this time last month!

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2014_02_12dp.jpg

17"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 5x3mins. RGB: 1x3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Sent: Saturday, 8 February 2014, 21:27
Subject: Two comets pass each other (Feb 8th, 2014.)

Hi all,

Here is C/2013 R1 and C/2012 X1 within the same field. They are presently moving apart fairly quickly and the last few days they have been at their closest. Luckily the weather finally cooperated to catch them together.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_x1_2014_02_08dp.jpg

106mm F5 with STL-11k camera. 2 frame mosaic. LRGB. L: 20mins. RGB: 3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Fri, 28 Feb 2014 14:26:51 +0100
From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Image C/2012 K1 (PANSTARRS)
http://cometografia.es/2014/02/2012k1-panstarrs-27feb2014/
Image of the comet C/2012 K1 PANSTARRS on February 27 in which is registered a great evolution since my last image taken on 2th. Its brightness has increased from 12.5 until 11.5 magnitude aproximately, meanwhile the coma only has increased a bit over 1' diameter with a white-greenish color. On the other hand seems that the comet is developing a very short tail toward southeast. The object at right border of the image is the spiral barred galaxy NGC 6181.

Regards.

José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo 
Date:  Sat, 01 Mar 2014 16:17:23 +0100

Rolando Ligustri

Date:  Sat, 01 Mar 2014 18:18:03 +0200
From:  Helder Geraldes 
Subject:  Alteração na HEQ-5
Helder Geraldes adicionou 6
fotos novas.
O meu grande amigo Manuel Fernandes,
www.astrofotografia.biz,
fez-me mais uma grande oferta: um sistema GOTO LXD55, um sistema GOTO
HEQ-5, um sistema GOTO EQ6+FS2 e uma Canon EOS D60 no final do ano passado
de 2013. Até ao momento, tive muito poucas oportunidades de experimentar e
treinar estes sistemas, porque o tempo não tem colaborado. Finalmente,
ontem, tive uma janela no céu que me permitiu testar um aperfeiçoamento e
fazer umas fotos de teste.
O aperfeiçoamento consistiu em substituir a luneta incorporada nos sistemas
para encontrar o polo Norte ou Sul celeste. Para mim que estou no
hemisfério Sul, esta luneta é quase inutil, como sabem os astrofotógrafos
do hemisfério Sul. Então, lembrei-me de substituir a luneta por um ponteiro
Laser verde. Com ele e a ajuda de um telescópio instalado no sistema,
torna-se simples encontrar o Sul e até alinhar o telescópio de forma a
ficar alinhado com o sistema. Após perder algum tempo para encontrar (não
fazia a mínima ideia de onde se encontrava ) o Sul, consegui as fotos que
se seguem. Na foto onde se vê o Laser, indico com ele a localização do Sul.
Usei uma Canon 300D também oferecida pelo Manuel Fernandes, com uma lente
de 50mm e 1 minuto de exposição com iso 100 no sistema HEQ-5 parqueado. As
outras fotos foram feitas com a mesma máquina, no mesmo HEQ-5, mas com uma
lente de 500mm f5.6 também oferecida pelo meu amigo Manuel Fernandes,
usando um iso de 1600 uma exposição de 178s para a nebulosa da Tarântula,
118 seg para a nébula do Orion, para a Ómega do Centauro, e para a
eta-Carinae. Todas estas fotos são frame único e foram tratadas com o
ACDSee.

Um grande agradecimento para este meu grande amigo que me tornou possível
realizar este meu sonho de toda a minha vida.

Esta minha alteração é simples de realizar, não é necessária qualquer
alteração irreversível e simplifica muito o alinhamento do sistema.O mais
crítico é o alinhamento do Laser, mas não é complicado. Estou disponível
para qualquer ajuda nesta alteração atravéz das redes sociais e grupos em
que estou inscrito.

Abraço,
Céus limpos,

Helder Geraldes

http://www.facebook.com/geraldes.helder

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2014A4SonearChile.htm

C 2013 Y2 PanStarrs
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2013Y2PanstarrsChile.htm

29P S-W1, outburst : mag 17.2 03/02, mag 14.5 03/03 = +/- 2.7 mag in about ten hours.
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image29PschwassmannwachmannChile.html

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/France
Date:  Mon, 03 Mar 2014 03:45:44 -0800
From:  Charles Bell 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Observation of comets 20140302 and 03
The tail and coma of comet C/2014 C2 (STEREO) have developed very nicely in your images. This is remarkable considering the absolute magnitude  of the comet is 18.  Fascinating. Thank you for posting.

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy (Mar 1st, 2014.)
Hi all,

Here is C/2013 R1 from March 1st. Its now moving into the dense star fields of the Milkyway and you can see various dust obscured regions within the field.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2014_03_01dp.jpg

17"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 5x3mins. RGB: 1x3mins.

Damian

scale or whatever to bring the comet out.

Date:  Sat, 08 Mar 2014 03:31:14 +0100
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2014-03-07 C2013E1 (fragment?) C2013TW5 C2014AA52
Dear all
Here are the images of this night. I ended with C/2013 E1 and the images
show a blob in the trail of the nucleus and 7 arcsec from nucleus.
The blob is visible in 2 stacked images made of 20 sub each. The comet
is about mag=19.1. I measured the nucleus
to about mag 19.8 with astrometrica, but I guess it's a too faint value,
because the blob is even about 1 mag fainter, but can't
be at mag 21... I would say the nucleus is rather at 19.2 and the blob
around 20.2.
Comments and confirmation from larger telescopes welcome !

C/2013 E1 McNaught, CLR filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013E1_McNaught.html

and also

C/2013 TW5 Spacewatch, Sloan r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013TW5_Spacewatch.html

C/2014 AA52, Sloan r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2014AA52_Catalina.html

Cheers
Luc 
Date:  Fri, 07 Mar 2014 23:27:42 -0500
From:  Mike Mattei 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014-03-07 C2013E1 (fragment?) C2013TW5 C2014AA52
Hello Luc

I notice a bright object just outside of the circle at the left of the 6 o-clock position on your image of C/2013 E1 McNaught, do you know what it is?

Mike

----- Original Message -----
From: Luc ARNOLD
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, March 07, 2014 9:31 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2014-03-07 C2013E1 (fragment?) C2013TW5 C2014AA52

Dear all
Here are the images of this night. I ended with C/2013 E1 and the images show a blob in the trail of the nucleus and 7 arcsec from nucleus.
The blob is visible in 2 stacked images made of 20 sub each. The comet is about mag=19.1. I measured the nucleus
to about mag 19.8 with astrometrica, but I guess it's a too faint value, because the blob is even about 1 mag fainter, but can't
be at mag 21... I would say the nucleus is rather at 19.2 and the blob around 20.2.
Comments and confirmation from larger telescopes welcome !

C/2013 E1 McNaught, CLR filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013E1_McNaught.html

and also

C/2013 TW5 Spacewatch, Sloan r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013TW5_Spacewatch.html

C/2014 AA52, Sloan r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2014AA52_Catalina.html

Cheers
Luc 


Date:  Sat, 08 Mar 2014 10:52:42 +0100
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014-03-07 C2013E1 (fragment?) C2013TW5 C2014AA52
Hello Mike
It's 2670 Chuvashia, which has almost the same proper motion than the comet.
L

> Hello Luc
> I notice a bright object just outside of the circle at the left of the
> 6 o-clock position on your image of C/2013 E1 McNaught, do you know
> what it is?
> Mike
>

----- Original Message -----
From: Luc ARNOLD

Hello Mike
It's 2670 Chuvashia, which has almost the same proper motion than the comet.
L

Le 08/03/2014 05:27, Mike Mattei a écrit :

Hello Luc

I notice a bright object just outside of the circle at the left of the 6 o-clock position on your image of C/2013 E1 McNaught, do you know what it is?

Mike

----- Original Message -----
From: Luc ARNOLD
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Friday, March 07, 2014 9:31 PM
Subject: [Comet-Images] 2014-03-07 C2013E1 (fragment?) C2013TW5 C2014AA52

Dear all
Here are the images of this night. I ended with C/2013 E1 and the images show a blob in the trail of the nucleus and 7 arcsec from nucleus.
The blob is visible in 2 stacked images made of 20 sub each. The comet is about mag=19.1. I measured the nucleus
to about mag 19.8 with astrometrica, but I guess it's a too faint value, because the blob is even about 1 mag fainter, but can't
be at mag 21... I would say the nucleus is rather at 19.2 and the blob around 20.2.
Comments and confirmation from larger telescopes welcome !

C/2013 E1 McNaught, CLR filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013E1_McNaught.html

and also

C/2013 TW5 Spacewatch, Sloan r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013TW5_Spacewatch.html

C/2014 AA52, Sloan r' filter
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2014AA52_Catalina.html

Cheers
Luc

Date:  Sat, 08 Mar 2014 13:02:20 -0800
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs K5 this morning
Greetings all,

Finally, a clear morning here in northern Arizona! This month has been rough due to a plentitude of high clouds and high winds. This morning it was clear, and with the moon set, we shot three comets. This first posting is of Panstarrs K5. What a peculiar looking comet. Here is the posting:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/panstarrsk5-030814.html

Thanks for looking! The other two comets are in processing. (Lovejoy and Linear X1)

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sun, 09 Mar 2014 11:59:06 +0100
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  2014-03-08 C2013E1
Dear all
I re-observed C/2013 E1 yesterday evening, with a higher and brighter
moon, but couldn't detect
that blob near the comet nucleus anymore. So it was probably noise
(maybe enhanced by a very
faint signal from the tail or coma ?). Jean Francois Soulier also imaged
the comet with the 400mm
CAO telescope in Chile (W96), and could not confirm that structure.

http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/C2013E1_McNaught.html

Best
Luc 
Date:  Sun, 09 Mar 2014 07:04:52 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comets Lovejoy and LInear X1
Hello All,

Extreme wind here in Arizona yesterday and today! These two images shows some pretty large stars, but the comets seem to have faired well. Looks like Lovejoy is developing some sort of fan tail now:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/comets030814.html

Thanks for looking!

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Mon, 10 Mar 2014 23:15:23 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy amongst the Milkyway (March 10th.)


Hi all,

Here is a long exposure image of Comet Lovejoy amongst the dense star clouds and dark nebulae of the Milkyway (currently in Serpens Cauda heading southward.)

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_r1_2014_03_10dp.jpg

FSQ106 with STL-11k camera. LRGB. L: 45mins. RGB: 5mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

From:  "José J. Chambó" 
Subject:  Image C/2012 X1 LINEAR
http://cometografia.es/2014/03/2012x1-linear-10mar2014/
In spite of it is a bit more brilliant that two months ago (now is near 8.2 magnitude) and increase its coma until 5' diameter, the dust tail of the comet C/2012 X1 LINEAR has been diluted until be barely visible with 10' longitude in this image.

Regards.

José J. Chambó (Valencia, Spain)blog: cometografia.es twitter: @PepeChambo

Date:  Sun, 16 Mar 2014 17:24:29 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet 134P/Kowal-Vavrova (March 10th.)
Hi all,

Here is periodic comet 134P captured on March 10th. Comes to perihelion in late May (last return was 1998.) Its around 13th magnitude at present located in Virgo roughly midway between Mars and Saturn.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/134p_2014_03_10dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 7x3mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
************************************************* 
Date:  Sun, 16 Mar 2014 22:06:52 +0000
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2014 E2 (Jacques) - March 16th
Hi all,

Here is an image of newly discovered comet C/2014 E2. A full moon ~40deg away made things challenging.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_e2_2014_03_16dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 8x2mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Date:  Tue, 18 Mar 2014 08:25:15 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] update observations 29P

Date:  Thu, 27 Mar 2014 07:39:34 +0100
From:  francois Kugel 
Subject:  C/2006S3 (LONEOS)
Hello everyone,

The comet crosses near M104 (Sombrero). This morning it was a little
low in the southwest sky and not top,
but I took the opportunity to shoot a small colorized;-)

http://comet.observations.free.fr/display-obs1.php?Num=11466

Francois

--
Francois KUGEL
Observatoire chante-perdrix
Dauban
04150 BANON - France
MPC station # A77

Michael,

that there was a very fine plasma tail to see!
http://www.astronomie.be/alfons.diepvens/cometimages/new/new34.html

On the photo of you it is also nice to see

(or see attachment of your image)

Hopefully develops these tail itself and we get to see beautiful comet !!

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2014 E2 (Jacques) - April 1st
Hi all,

Here is C/2014 E2 captured on April 1st. Very distinct green colouration to the coma.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2014_e2_2014_04_02dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 8x2mins. RGB: 1x2mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Erik Bryssinck

Date:  Sun, 06 Apr 2014 19:06:16 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2012 K1 (April 4th.)
Hi all,

Here is a colour image of C/2012 K1 from April 4th. The very weak ion tail can just be seen. Also a very weak greenish coma was captured (clearly seen when flicking between the RGB data.)

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_k1_2014_04_04dp.jpg

17"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 8x3mins. RGB: 1x3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Date:  Mon, 07 Apr 2014 09:27:39 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comets Panstarrs K1 and Lovejoy R1 Yesterday morning
Greetings Comet Friends,

Very windy here in Arizona this time of year, I was able to get a deep shot of Panstarrs, but Lovejoy got cut short because the guide star was lost in the wind. I still got a decent shot of it against an area of plenty of dark nebula.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/comets040614.html

Panstarrs is starting to shows some green coloration in the head!

Clear Skies,

Chris

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2006 S3 (LONEOS) - April 8th
Hi all,

Here is C/2006 S3 from April 8th. A very narrow looking tail is visible extending ~10 arc mins in length.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2006_s3_2014_04_08dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 30mins. RGB: 3mins.

Date:  Thu, 10 Apr 2014 19:41:35 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2012 X1 (LINEAR) - April 8th
Hi all,

Here is C/2012 X1 from April 8th. Most seem to have forgotten about this comet but its certainly well worth observing. Some nice gas tail streamers can be seen which i didn't expect.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_x1_2014_04_08dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 25mins. RGB: 3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Subject:  Equipment for sale

Date:  Wed, 16 Apr 2014 22:55:26 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Equipment for sale
Hi Mike,

Just type astrobuysell.com into google and it will come up with UK, USA, and Canada sites. These are good places to sell equipment. You will probably have to register with them to post adverts.

What equipment are you selling?
Best wishes
Denis Buczynski

ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

Hello

April 16 UT 19.10 10"/3.8 FLI 8300
L2x210sec UV/IR green 400, blue 400 red 300 sec

Michael Jäger 
Date:  Wed, 16 Apr 2014 18:31:13 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2014 E2 Jacques LRGB after fullmoon
Beautiful, particularly considering the low declination.
This is beginning to look a lot like Comet Holmes at its peak, with the very strong stellar nucleus and uniform spherical thin but large coma.

Thanks for posting.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

From:  walcom77 
Subject:  Comet 209P imaged on 2014, April 14.95
Hi All

Blog updated with our recent obs of comet 209P (taken with the 2-meter
Liverpool Telescope by miself and N. Howes, B. Mueller, M. Nicolini,
N. Samarasinha) and some info about its possible meteor shower:

http://bit.ly/1hZ7k4h

Ciao,
Ernesto Guido
http://remanzacco.blogspot.com
http://twitter.com/comets77 

Date:  Thu, 17 Apr 2014 20:16:24 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  image new comet C/2014 G3 (PANSTARRS)
CCD-Image taken on apr. 16.09 2014 , while it was still mentioned on the
PCCP of the minor planet center, by use of 0.4-m f/3.8 AG16 astrograph from
BRIXIIS Observatory (IAU: B96), Kruibeke, Belgium and with CLEAR filter..
Object was a very faint comet and hard to see on the CCD-images - stacking
of several images was necesarry, object has a circular coma of about 11 arc.
sec. Data obtained from eight co-added images of 180 sec. each. I could
measure a total magnitude of about 19.1. This object was assigned via
CBET nr.
3845 as comet C/2014 G3 (PANSTARRS) on apr. 17 2014. My observations are
included in the
M.P.E.C. 2014-H04

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2014g2_20140416.html

___________________________________

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck

BRIXIIS Observatory (MPC:B96)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/

___________________________________

CARA - Cometary Archive for Af(rho) : http://cara.uai.it

VVS - Belgian association for amateur astronomers : http://www.vvs.be

Date:  Thu, 24 Apr 2014 19:38:02 +0200
From:  chrismlt@laposte.net
Subject:  Comet 2014 E2 Jacques and 124P

Dear all,

An image of comet 2014 E2 Jacques with FS102 F6 refractor.
The comet was visible with 11x70 bino for the first time from here (Drôme, France) as a small patch at only 20° above the horizon.
m1 = 10.5 ; m2 = 8.5 probably. Tail = 4-5' long pa 107°.
The coma can be mesured as 7x8' total with a log filter on the image.

Also a photo through clouds of comet 124P Mrkos. Only a small dot to be seen m2 = 17.0 +/- 0.2
No coma/tail. Then, suddenly some clouds came and the sky was overcast.

Images here :
https://www.flickr.com/photos/93826649@N04/

Cheers,
Christophe

Date:  Fri, 25 Apr 2014 13:18:16 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs K1 now in Evening sky!
Greetings Comet friends,

A clear night last night before the big winter storm rolls in later today, so I took advantage of the now evening apparition of this comet to get a deeper exposure. I can use 2 min subs now, the comet is moving slow enough to do this.

This is a true LRGB image. I did 60 mins of L channel, and 6 mins of RGB. To colorize the star trails, let me fill you in on a neat processing trick.. If you paste the RGB stars over the L channel data with star trails as many times as you have subs for the L channel - in this case 30 times, combine with color on the layers and shift each layer to color a star in the trail. Obviously you have to mask out the comets core when you do this!

Last nights shot:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/pannstarrsk1-042414.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Mon, 28 Apr 2014 09:56:35 +1000
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C2014E2 the hard way
easier to see with bigger equipment...
Got a good break last night. The afternoon southerly breezes slowed to
still air. A cool and clear night with good seeing. So popped out the
ED80mm and 450d Dslr on the eq6. Alignment was good for 30 sec images
stacks of 10 images.

Got C/3014 E2 Jacques and a few of the old fave's.

images at this blog near the end....

http://cometal-comets.blogspot.com.a...2-jacques.html

kind regards, Al.

Date:  Tue, 29 Apr 2014 12:39:23 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Comet C/2012K1 image 20140428
Hello all,
I imaged this comet last night and was able to record the broad ion tail and the faint outer coma that this comet now displays.
The image is located within the Comet Image Archive of the British Astronomical Association at the following links:

http://www.britastro.org/cometobs/

http://www.britastro.org/cometobs/2012k1/2012k1_20140428_2330_dgb.html

Best wishes
Denis Buczynski
Secretary Comet Section

British Astronomical Association

Date:  Mon, 05 May 2014 18:21:15 -0700
From:  roman.kulesza@hotmail.com
Subject:  Comet C/2012 K1 on 28April 2012
Hello,
I like to share with you my last shot of comet C/2012 K1 PanSTARRS
This time I used 10"inch /0.25M/ at F-5 my home made newtonian with conical R.F Royce mirror.
Moded Canon Xsi camera ,20 exposures X 3 minutes plus full calibration .
https://www.flickr.com/photos/romanastrophotography/14042283356/in/photostream/ https://www.flickr.com/photos/romanastrophotography/14042283356/in/photostream/
Was bad seeing and dew on my mirror.
All the best.
Roman
PS
I process my comet images as deep sky object so Ion tail is not much visible
Thanks for looking

> stacks of 10 images.

Date:  Thu, 08 May 2014 23:39:22 +1200
From:  john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Subject:  P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 1 (29P) imaged on 2014 May 06 UT
Hi,

I took some images of P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 1 (29P) 48 hours ago (2014 May 06 UT) with a 35cm f10 Meade ACF SCT and STL11000M CCD. I stacked 20 x 2 minute exposures. There appears to be a shell of material ~0’.6 across in the southern region of the comet – below the ‘nucleus’. Could this half-shell perhaps have anything to do with the recent magnitude increase of 29P – or would that outburst have dissipated by now?

The image can be seen at -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/29P-Shwassmann-Wachmann-35cm_f10-SCT-20x2min-clear-1x1-2014May06-drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/mxb8bwe

Regards
==============================
John Drummond
Gisborne Astronomical Society president - www.astrogas.co.nz
GAS Facebook - https://www.facebook.com/gisborneastronomicalsociety?ref=stream&hc_location=timeline
Possum Observatory Complex
International Astro Union Code: E94
Gisborne, New Zealand
E: 177d 53', S: 38d 38'
Email: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Website: www.possumobservatory.co.nz
Images: http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/latest_images-all-continuing.htm
Phone (mobile): 0275 609 287
Date:  Thu, 08 May 2014 09:24:05 -0700

From: john_drummond@xtra.co.nz
Sent: Thursday, May 08, 2014 9:39 PM

Subject: [asvcometsection] P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 1 (29P) imaged on 2014 May 06 UT [1 Attachment]

[Attachment(s) from john_drummond@xtra.co.nz included below]

Hi,

I took some images of P/Schwassmann-Wachmann 1 (29P) 48 hours ago (2014 May 06 UT) with a 35cm f10 Meade ACF SCT and STL11000M CCD. I stacked 20 x 2 minute exposures. There appears to be a shell of material ~0’.6 across in the southern region of the comet – below the ‘nucleus’. Could this half-shell perhaps have anything to do with the recent magnitude increase of 29P – or would that outburst have dissipated by now?

The image can be seen at -
http://www.possumobservatory.co.nz/29P-Shwassmann-Wachmann-35cm_f10-SCT-20x2min-clear-1x1-2014May06-drummond-web.jpg
or
http://tinyurl.com/mxb8bwe

Regards
==============================
John Drummond

Date:  Fri, 09 May 2014 17:33:27 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2012 K1 on May 9th via New Mexico
NICE Martin! I have finally got my act together and put our ziess APO on the back of the 12 inch for some CCD work. I plan on this comet first - hopefully a test shot tonight to see if I can guide and get a coma free shot. I think as seen well in your shot, that this very faint ion tail will be a great target for us, the magazines will go nuts for a really good shot of the two tails.

Keep up the good work,

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Sat, 10 May 2014 10:59:50 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Finally, new CCD setup for Panstarrs K1 last night!
Hello everyone,

We bolted our Stellarvue 80mm f/4.7 (EFR) on the side of the 12.5" newt, and gave it a first test with the ST10xme CCD last night on the comet. Of course the moon made the whole sky blue, but it was a good time for checking out this setup. This APO has all Ziess optics, and performed admirably with the .8x televue FR/CC attached directly to the filter wheel t mount.

With the comet showing this long ion tail, it was time for a wider field, and for future comets this will be a great setup. So without delay, here are our first test results with this instrument and CCD:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/PanstarrsK1-051014.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sat, 10 May 2014 15:46:05 -0700
From:  "Richard \Rik\"
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Finally, new CCD setup for Panstarrs K1 last night!
Very nice image even with moon. I think I like a cool blue background
like that.

-Rik

Date:  Fri, 16 May 2014 10:21:07 -0700
From:  Soulier Jean-FranÃ§ois 
Subject:  Observation of comet
Good evening.

T300 :

C 2014 J1 Catalina (new comet)
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2014J1Catalinafrance.htm

C 2012 K1 PanStarrs, Red Filter J/C
http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageC2012K1Panstarrsfrance.htm

T400RC Remote, SpaceObs, A.Maury, Chile :

29P S-W1, new Outburst (highlighted by J. Drummond)

In 20140507.31 => m2 : 15.9
In 20140513.34 => m2 : 14.6 (R.O : 5.5")
Coma : +/- 20"x25"
Clear filter.

29P S-W1, Clear and I Bessel 20140514,053
R.O : 4.76"= 10000km => mag : 15.30
R.O : 6.12"= 13000km => mag : 14.82
star Ref. : F8/G0V
R.O : 5.5"= Astrometrica => m2 : 15.1

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/image29PschwassmannwachmannChile.html

K13U04Q (still no cometary designation)
Coma 17"x25", tail : 19"
PA between 285° and 300°
m2 : 15.8 (+/-0.2), R.O : 6.9"

http://6888comete.free.fr/fr/imageK13U04QChile.htm

Sincerely.
SOULIER Jean-François
C10/France 

Date:  Fri, 16 May 2014 20:15:15 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  image new comet C/2014 J1 (CATALINA)
Hello,

Here my image of the new comet C/2014 J1 (CATALINA)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2014j1_20140516.html

it looks more a starlike object on this image. I could see some more
cometary features on the first images, when the moon was lower to the
horizon. Moonlight was very disturbing (44°) from object. Also a slightly
hint of a tail, but too uncertain to report. The tail that I could see was
heading north - east with p.a. of 46 °. But like I said, only visible on
the 6 first images. Not easy to catch with a speed of 6.25 arc.sec/min. and
magnitude 19.

___________________________________

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck

BRIXIIS Observatory (MPC:B96)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/

___________________________________

CARA - Cometary Archive for Af(rho) : http://cara.uai.it

VVS - Belgian association for amateur astronomers : http://www.vvs.be

Date:  Mon, 19 May 2014 10:23:50 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs K1 last night - an imagers challenge!
Hi all,

Panstarrs K1 continues to be a challange to image, its very dim gas tail is long and now streaked with long rays. Here I have added some additional bracing to my astrograph support plates and can now go at least 5 mins with a separate guide scope and get clean sharp images. This is perfect for our prey - moving comets against a starry backdrop.

The data is on the page, basically it was a 80mm f/4.8 Stellarvue / Ziess APO and ST10xme CCD. for 75 minutes total.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/panstarrsk1-051814.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  images comet C/2012 X1 and C/2014 E2
Images of comet C/2014 E2 (JACQUES) and C/2012 X1 (LINEAR) to obtain
astrometry, photometry and Af(rho) parameter.

All this data and images can you find via link below:

Comet C/2014 E2 (JACQUES) on 12 may 2014

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2014e2_20140512.html

comet C/2012 X1 (LINEAR) on 13 may 2014

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2012x1_20140513.html

comet C/2014 E2 (JACQUES) on 14 may 2014

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2014e2_20140514.html

Date:  Tue, 20 May 2014 19:33:48 +0200
From:  chrismlt@laposte.net
Subject:  Comet 2014 E2 Jacques, 2012 K1 Panstarrs, 209P and 29P
Dear all,

Some images taken on 17/05/2017 with a FS102 refractor from Drôme, France.
Jacques was only 5° above the horizon, and 29P only 13.5°.
209P shows a 9' tail and K1 Panstarrs 2 tails 15' and 9' long.

Images are here :
https://www.flickr.com/photos/93826649@N04/

Cheers,
Christophe

From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at

Date:  Mon, 26 May 2014 13:19:46 +0200
From:  Castell 
Subject:  2012 K1 from Vienna
Panstarrs 2012/K1 on May21 2014, 10" f/4 Newtonian, Eos6d. Location near Vienna/Austria.
40x2min exposures at Iso800 were stacked on stars and on comet and brought together.

link to a 800kb pic:
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/87975652/Panstarrs_2012K1_20140521_10Nf4_Eos6d.jpg

link to a 5Mb pic:
https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/87975652/Panstarrs_2012K1_20140521_10Nf4_Eos6da.jpg

Tommy Nawratil

Date:  Tue, 27 May 2014 06:38:44 -0700
From:  jean-gabriel bosch 
Subject:  obs 2014-05-27 C2013A1, 134P, C2013US10, 44P
Hello everyone,

Remote T400RC SpaceObs A.Maury

C2013A1 (Siding Spring)  difficult capture,  comet at about 10 ° from the horizon and guide camera down
This is the first step in the MPC since 2014-03-30
Bright, magnitude 15.3 PA 330 ° coma17 "tail 1'30" structure PA 320 to 0°

http://comet.observations.free.fr/display-obs1.php?Num=11852

134P

http://comet.observations.free.fr/display-obs1.php?Num=11855

C2013US10

http://comet.observations.free.fr/display-obs1.php?Num=11853

44P

http://comet.observations.free.fr/display-obs1.php?Num=11854

Regards,
JG Bosch

Date:  Thu, 29 May 2014 11:33:02 +0200
From:  chrismlt@laposte.net
Subject:  209P
Dear all,

An image of comet 209P as seen from Drôme, France.
2014 05 27 from  21h45 UT.
FS102 refractor f6, 121x37 sec exp, 6400 iso.
The tail was 35' long and appears slightly curvated - see log filter image for best effect.
The comet was relatively low on the horizon (25° to 13°) during the exposure, so the airmass increased, hiding the most tenuous part of the tail.
https://www.flickr.com/photos/93826649@N04/

Cheers,
Christophe
Date:  Thu, 29 May 2014 12:02:37 +0200

Date:  Fri, 30 May 2014 13:35:54 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Comet 209P/Linear: 29 May
Dear All,

here it is the last picture I was able to capture, while the
comet was setting, less than 30 deg above the SW horizon,
during the astronomical twilight: very far from ideal
conditions!

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2014/05/30/comet-209plinear-minimum-distance-image-29-2014/

best
Gianluca 

Date:  Fri, 30 May 2014 13:00:26 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs K1 last night - Blazing star nearly on top!
Hello All,

After finding out that Linear 209P was in the trees before dark at our observatory in the back yard, I panned over to K1 and went as long as I could before it too went into the trees to the west of us. This relatively deep exposure was nearly ruined by the blazing star Omega Uma, which is 4.6 magnitude and nearly right on the comets tail. Thanks for looking:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/PanstarrsK1-052914.html

Clear Skies,

Chris Schur

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Fri, 30 May 2014 20:18:01 -0700
From:  hiroc070717@yahoo.com
Subject:  Comet 209P LINEAR May 29, 2014
Dear members,

I could enjoy imaging of the comet about 3 hours after the closest encounter with the Earth by 0.055AU.
209p/Ninear 2014-5-29 12:25-13:01utc https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/14119352170/

https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/14119352170/

209p/Ninear 2014-5-29 12:25-13:01utc https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/14119352170/ The comet flied near the earth by 0.055AU about 3 hours before this imaging. The object moved fast, and it traced a little during each exposure for...

View on www.flickr.com https://www.flickr.com/photos/hiroc/14119352170/
Preview by Yahoo

The image showed lovely curved short tail.
The comet moved fast, and it showed trailing during each exposure for one minute.

Hisayoshi Kato 

Date:  Sat, 31 May 2014 13:54:44 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Panstarrs K1 with the Ziess APO last night
Greetings all,

to compiment my prime focus shot I posted yesterday, I took another deep look at this comet, but with the 80mm f/4.7 astrograph and did 90 minutes to try to get more of that pesky dim gas tail. And dim it is! Even after this amount of time, it is still qute faint, despite our jet black skies over head. hopeing it brightens up a bit over the next month...

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/panstarrsK1-053014.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

4 comets observed this evening, good seeing, high moisture

From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Lovejoy R1 in Scorpius
Hello All,

It was great to get one last parting shot of this comet as it heads off in to the depths of the solar system. Here is a moderately deep exposure taken last night and the comet STILL has a nice fan tail!

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Lovejoy053114.html

Date:  Fri, 06 Jun 2014 23:24:57 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  C 2014E 2 with structured ion tail
Hello everybody,

This image was taken some hours ago. Despite the moon and altitude at
imaging (I end up at 4°) the comets tail looks already impressive.
Unfortunately the red channel of the RGB data is not really good  thus I
have only stacked the Luminance to show:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/214_2014E2_June6.jpg

Have good one

Gerald 

Date:  Sat, 07 Jun 2014 10:08:04 +1000
From:  Alan Watson 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C 2014E 2 with structured ion tail
Reports in the Stereo Hunter forum, have seen Jacques in lower left quarter
of HI2B, not the best images,over the last few weeks. Growing in brightness
due to proximity approach to satellite. Also showing ION tail dynamics
across periods of a day..

May be ground opportunity to show dynamic tail interactions with solar wind?

kind regards, Alan Watson

Here is C/2012 X1 (LINEAR) from June 5th. Poor weather prevented any colour data, or indeed the intended mosaic alongside the Helix Nebula.....sigh.....

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2012_x1_2014_06_05dp.jpg

106mm F5. STL-11k. 4x3mins unfiltered.

Damian

Subject:  Comet C/2012 X1  - June 8th
Hi all,

Date:  Mon, 16 Jun 2014 17:44:51 +0800
From:  amar sharma 
Subject:  William Bradfield passes away!
Hello comet world,

I regret to inform you all that William Bradfield, the the legendary comet hunter who discovered all 18 visual comet-bradfields, passed away on June 9 at age 86. He had been suffering from prolonged illness. Rodney Austin informs me of this after which I bring it to you. The world quite does not know about it yet; nothing even on Google. But there has been a discussion going on an Australian forum about it, which confirms the fact:

http://www.iceinspace.com.au/forum/showthread.php?t=122117

I have just sent an Obituary write up on William Bradfield to S&T.com and Astronomy.com. I hope it officially comes up soon.

This is a very tragic loss for our comet community. RIP Bradfield. :-(

Regards, Amar.
Date:  Mon, 16 Jun 2014 21:11:10 +1000
From:  Dave Herald 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] William Bradfield
Bill’s passing is sad news.

I first had contact with Bill back in 1972 as a result of his first comet discovery. That led me into doing astrometry of comets, which I still do today. For the 70’s and ‘80’s there was an ongoing contest between myself, Alan Gilmore (Mt John Observatory, New Zealand) and Mike Candy (Perth Observatory) to get astrometry over 3 nights of Bill’s new discoveries - to enable an orbit to be computed (there were only the three of us doing cometary astrometry from the southern hemisphere back then.) In those years a phone call from Bill almost inevitably resulted in a string of early mornings trying to get the required astrometry.

I remember Bill as a somewhat shy but affable man who was very self-deprecating about his discoveries. He encouraged others to search for comets, and happily shared his knowledge about where to search for comets (he had a very definite search strategy!) These days the visual discovery of comets is relatively rare, and his achievements in the visual discovery of comets are unlikely to ever be equalled. I feel honoured to have known him.

Dave Herald
Murrumbateman, NSW
Australia

---
This email is free from viruses and malware because avast! Antivirus protection is active.
http://www.avast.com

Clear Skies,

Chris

Date:  Mon, 16 Jun 2014 17:01:21 +0100
From:  denis buczynski 
Subject:  Re: [comets-ml] William Bradfield passes away!
Very sad news that Bill Bradfield has passed away. He will always be remembered as one of the all time great visual comet discoverers. I think I am correct in thinking that he had the unique distinction of having all his comet discoveries named only after himself ,with no other observer sharing the discovery. A remarkable achievement indeed. His discoveries were so numerous that I expect that ,like myself, most comet observers were never surprised to hear of yet anther comet discovery by him. Those discoveries have been appreciated and enjoyed by all who love comet observing. He was an observer without equal, he will be sadly missed by us all.

 Commiserations to his family and close friends from The Comet Section of The British Astronomical Association
Denis Buczynski

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets/216_K1_1506bw.jpg

Gerald

Date:  Tue, 17 Jun 2014 20:15:35 +0200
From:  Erik Bryssinck 
Subject:  images new comet C/2014 L2 (NEOWISE) on 12 + 15 june
While this possible comet was still mentioned on the PCCP of the minor
planet center, I did observations from my observatory with a 0.4-m f/3.8
astrograph on 12 and 15 june.

Later on 15 june, Cbet nr. 3901 was issued and announced the discovery of
the comet C/2014 L2 (NEOWISE)

Observations and images can you find:

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/c2014l2.html

___________________________________

kind regards,

Erik Bryssinck

BRIXIIS Observatory (MPC:B96)

http://www.astronomie.be/erik.bryssinck/

___________________________________

CARA - Cometary Archive for Af(rho) : http://cara.uai.it

VVS - Belgian association for amateur astronomers : http://www.vvs.be

From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  C/2012 K1 very faint ion tails
Hello everybody,

I took that images last evening from Namibia. As one can see the ion tails
are very faint stuff. Thus I have prepared an inverted few as well. RGB data
will be processed those days.

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/217_K1_1806bw.jpg

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/218_K1_1806bw2.jpg

Gerald

Date:  Fri, 20 Jun 2014 12:44:27 +0200
From:  Gerald Rhemann 
Subject:  2012 K1 LRGB June 18
Hi

This is my color version of K1 from June 18:

Date:  Fri, 20 Jun 2014 17:28:49 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet C/2012 K1 Panstarrs large field
hello Gerald. true, but you have to consider that I used an optical very short, and,
from experience, this allows a better perception of weak details. Then I applied a
technique that dates back to the times of the comet Elenin, using a plug-in for
AstroArt that allows me to highlight the details weak, then a passage in PS and
you're done.

regards
Rolando

Subject:  MPC /LastCometObs.html
All - Just a short question: do you know why the list of the last
observed comets stops at C/2014 G1 and 300P, while new comets
have been discovered since ?

http://www.minorplanetcenter.net/iau/lists/LastCometObs.html

Luc 
Date:  Sat, 21 Jun 2014 18:13:25 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] MPC /LastCometObs.html
I have noticed this as well; sometimes it simply takes a while to get things in the queue.
Also note that MPC is running a bit short-staffed at the moment; with all of the lists and documentation that is generated daily, they have a lot to do for such a small staff.

------------
Dr. Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971

Date:  Thu, 03 Jul 2014 22:57:29 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  Possible fragment detached from 296P/Garradd nucleus
Dear all,

My last observations of 296P/Garradd on July 2.9 show a small object
following the comet nucleus.
The object is about mag 20, while the nucleus is around mag 18.8
(unfiltered).
A. Maury and J.-F. Soulier obtained confirmation images with a 0.4m f/8
RC telescope at W96, with that object
visible at the same position: 6'' in PA 220 from the nucleus.

Follow-up observations are welcome, especilly with large telescope.

All images (with an animated GIF) are at URL:
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/296P_Garradd.html

Best

Luc 

Date:  Thu, 03 Jul 2014 16:12:26 -0700
From:  chergen@yahoo.com
Subject:  Images of C/2013 UQ4 from the VATT
I was able to observe C/2013 UQ4 (Catalina) on 3 nights last week (June 24/25/26 UT) with the Vatican VATT 1.8-m telescope on Mount Graham.

It sure is a nice comet. In addition to the large, somewhat offset gas coma and strong curving dust jet, my images also show evidence of a weaker jet in the solar direction.

My images can be found on the ALPO Comet Section Image Gallery.

http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_itemId=5799 http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_itemId=5799

- Carl Hergenrother

ps. as ALPO Comet Section Coordinator, I'd like to solicit any and all comet images and magnitude estimates. You don't have to be a member of the ALPO to contribute though we would be very happy to have you join as well. 

Date:  Fri, 04 Jul 2014 10:33:10 -0000
From:  Martin Mobberley 
Subject:  2013 UQ4 on July 4th via itel New Mexico
A stack of 10 x 60s of 2013 UQ4 (Catalina) taken 2 hours ago:

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/images/2013uq4_20140704_mpm.jpg

Regards,
Martin

http://martinmobberley.co.uk/Comets.html 

Date:  Fri, 04 Jul 2014 15:42:17 +0200
From:  chrismlt@laposte.net
Subject:  Comets 2013 UQ4, 2012 K1 and 29P.
Hello,

Some images from 2014 07 2-3 with  FS102 f6 refractor.

Comet 2013 UQ4 : m2=13.84, tail 50' long, coma 7x9'.
The comet almost occulted a 12.00 star during exposure (near miss 2'' +-).

Comet 2012 K1 in twilight : m2=11.47.

Comet 29P : m1=16.58.

Images are visible here :
https://www.flickr.com/photos/93826649@N04/14568518471/in/photostream/

Cheers,
Christophe

Date:  Sun, 06 Jul 2014 23:21:13 +0200
From:  Luc ARNOLD 
Subject:  296P follow up
Dear all,
I observed again 296P, but the last images aren't very convincing concerning
the object observed near the comet nucleus 3 days ago. If this
condensation was
real, it was transient only. I put images and comments on my webpage
(including images from W96, A77 and Konkoly Observatory)
http://www.obs-hp.fr/~larnold/v2/LucArnold/296P_Garradd.html

Best

Luc

Subject:  2013E2 Jacques is back


Hello everybody,

Inspired by a discussion with Michael I tried to catch the comet this
morning. It really was a hard core issue and thus I only got two 60 second
images with 3x3 binning. But anyway here it is:

Dear All,

Date:  Fri, 11 Jul 2014 17:38:09 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  C/2013 UQ4 Catalina: compared views
Dear Comet enthusiasts,

I managed to put together my three images of c/2013 UQ4, collected over three
different nights:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2014/07/11/comet-c2013-uq4-catalina-evolution-minimum-distance-earth-9-10-11-july-2014/

It is a nice effect to see how the stars residuals on the background are showing
how the PA of motion evolved.

Also, the different aspect of the central condensation is interesting.

best
Gianluca

Date:  Fri, 11 Jul 2014 15:09:13 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4: 10 and 11 July
Gianluca, excellent point about the sheer number of stars hiding the comets faint tail. I just bought the software "nebuosity" which has sigma stack, cant wait to test this o on comets compared to median. Also the freeware "Deep Sky Stacker" is one hellova program for stacking comets, does a killer job on both median and sigma.

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Yahoo Groups Links

    Comet-Images-fullfeatured@yahoogroups.com 

Date:  Sun, 13 Jul 2014 20:05:30 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4 Catalina: five nights of observation
Hi Chris,

the mount (paramount ME) is tracking the comet in real time,
so that I can easily integrate (for 180-seconds in this
case) long enough.

each session consists of a number of those exposures, lately
median combined to "kill" the strong interference by those
very crowded stars.

I like to see how the residual star trails give an hint to
show how the PA of motion evolved around the close
encounter.

Best
Gianluca

Date:  Tue, 15 Jul 2014 08:38:34 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4: 15July
This is a beautiful image, but I am not a fan nor in favor of images that do not show
stars. Nearby stars are used, not only for magnitude comparisons, but also for
spectral relationships, precise position and other scientific purposes. This new
trend of "eliminating" the field stars in my opinion really is counterproductive to
true science.

Nonetheless, the comet's portrait in your image is very beautiful and reveals
considerable morphology.

------------
Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971
____________________

----- Original Message -----
From: "Gianluca Masi gianluca@bellatrixobservatory.org [Comet-Images]"

>
> here it is my latest image

> http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2014/07/15/comet-c2013-uq4-catalina-image-15-july-2014/

> best
> Gianluca

Date:  Tue, 15 Jul 2014 15:50:29 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4: 15July
Dear Clay,

you are right, I use to leave stars there; C/2013 UQ4, though, is crossing such
a dense star field that it is just difficult to look at its morphology otherwise.

I did a comparison here, where both an average and median combination (and the
former used less frames to limit the killing impact of star trails) are shown:

http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2014/07/10/comet-c2013-uq4-catalina-minimum-distance-earth-image-10-july-2014/

have dark and clear skies
Gian

Date:  Tue, 15 Jul 2014 11:13:54 -0700
From:  jean-gabriel bosch 
Subject:  C2014E2, C2013A1, C2014N3, 246P, 17P obs 15-07-2014
Hi,

http://transitionsciel.blogspot.fr/
Date:  Tue, 15 Jul 2014 13:34:01 -0700
From:  chergen@yahoo.com
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4: 15July

Hi Clay,

I'm going to respectfully disagree with you on your statement that the technique
Gianluca used on C/2013 UQ4 is "counterproductive to true science". Making
the stars "go away" via median or average filtering is a common technique
among researchers for pulling out faint comet morphologies (tails, trails, comae,
jets, etc.) from dense stellar backgrounds. You'll find plenty of published papers
using this technique (see http://arxiv.org/pdf/1209.2210v1.pdf http://arxiv.org/pdf/1209.2210v1.pdf for a nice example).
So I think it is valid to use this technique for showing the full extent of a comet
such as C/2013 UQ4 that is moving rapidly against a Milky Way background.
Plus the results are very good. Kudos to Gianluca!

Like all image processing techniques, it has pros and cons and one must be
careful in how the data is used and interpreted. Median/average filtering is good
for morphological studies but not for photometric or astrometric work. Though I'm
sure, Gianluca still has the individual images and these can still be used for
astrometry and photometry so that data is not lost.

Personally I use median filtering on my morphological data because it is an
efficient way to make my cosmic ray hits go away.

- Carl Hergenrother

---In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, wrote :

This is a beautiful image, but I am not a fan nor in favor of images that do not show
stars. Nearby stars are used, not only for magnitude comparisons, but also for
spectral relationships, precise position and other scientific purposes. This new
trend of "eliminating" the field stars in my opinion really is counterproductive to
true science.

Nonetheless, the comet's portrait in your image is very beautiful and reveals
considerable morphology.

------------
Clay

Arkansas Sky Observatories
http://www.arksky.org/ http://www.arksky.org/
ASO Petit Jean Mountain /MPC H41
ASO Petit Jean Mountain South /MPC H45
ASO West Conway /MPC H43
.......serving astronomy since 1971
____________________

Date:  Tue, 15 Jul 2014 16:05:08 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4: 15July
I believe that I did indicate that the process does enhance the physical aspects of the comet.
Also, I do believe that I commended the excellence of the image.
For various other purposes, however, the star field is essential.

I am quite familiar with the median technique but still find it troubling that it is gaining ground to the point that we are being presented pretty pictures of comets with no subjects to which to compare.
Perhaps both might be considered: one using the median filtering and one without, side-by-side so that both aspects can be utilized and enjoyed.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

----- Original Message -----
From: chergen@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Tuesday, July 15, 2014 3:34 PM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4: 15July

Hi Clay,

I'm going to respectfully disagree with you on your statement that the technique
Gianluca used on C/2013 UQ4 is "counterproductive to true science". Making
the stars "go away" via median or average filtering is a common technique
among researchers for pulling out faint comet morphologies (tails, trails, comae,
jets, etc.) from dense stellar backgrounds. You'll find plenty of published papers
using this technique (see http://arxiv.org/pdf/1209.2210v1.pdf for a nice example).
So I think it is valid to use t his technique for showing the full extent of a comet
such as C/2013 UQ4 that is moving rapidly against a Milky Way background.
Plus the results are very good. Kudos to Gianluca!

Like all image processing techniques, it has pros and cons and one must be
careful in how the data is used and interpreted. Median/average filtering is good
for morphological studies but not for photometric or astrometric work. Though I'm
sure, Gianluca still has the individual images and these can still be used for
astrometry and photometry so that data is not lost.

Personally I use median filtering on my morphological data because it is a n
efficient way to make my cosmic ray hits go away.

- Carl Hergenrother

---In Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com, wrote :

This is a beautiful image, but I am not a fan nor in favor of images that do not show
stars. Nearby stars are used, not only for magnitude comparisons, but also for
spectral relationships, precise position and other scientific purposes. This new
trend of "eliminating" the field stars in my opinion really is counterproductive to
true science.

Nonetheless, the comet's portrait in your image is very beautiful and reveals
considerable morphology.

Date:  Tue, 15 Jul 2014 16:27:17 -0500
From:  "P. Clay Sherrod" 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4: 15July
I can certainly understand that the delicate outer features of the comet might
"disappear" in the star field that the comet presently is in.
There are many very finely defined intricate gas structures showing in your image
that might not appear because of contrast problems with multitudes of faint stars.
Perhaps you might consider posting both a "raw" image with stars included alongside
one using median filtering to de-emphasize the stars.

At any rate, you have an excellent capture here.

Clay
_____
Dr. P. Clay Sherrod
Arkansas Sky Observatories
MPC H45 - Petit Jean Mountain South
MPC H41 - Petit Jean Mountain
MPC H43 - Conway West
http://www.arksky.org/

>
> you are right, I use to leave stars there; C/2013 UQ4, though, is crossing such
> a dense star field that it is just difficult to look at its morphology otherwise.

> I did a comparison here, where both an average and median combination (and the
> former used less frames to limit the killing impact of star trails) are shown:
>
> http://www.virtualtelescope.eu/2014/07/10/comet-c2013-uq4-catalina-minimum-distance-earth-image-10-july-2014/

Date:  Thu, 17 Jul 2014 21:23:38 +1000
From:  mmatti@westnet.com.au
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2014 E2 July 16 from Austria
Hi Chris,

Orbital plane crossing occurred around May 17 so we will see the dust tail start to widen out.
Unfortunately it will continue to point away from Earth, so I don’t expected it to be prominent until September, after its Earth approach.
The next orbital plane crossing will be around Nov 20. By then, the comet is quite distant from Earth.

cheers,
Michael Mattiazzo

Date:  Sat, 19 Jul 2014 17:31:50 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet C2013 Catalina UQ4 and some stacking experiments
Greetings all,

After nearly a month of completely cloudy skies both day and night, the Arizona monsoon rains paused for about 4 hours last night, and allowed me to get in some shots of this interesting comet. This comet is really moving fast against the background stars! A great oppourtinity to try out some different stacking techniques to see which shows the best faint tail details, and a new method for colorizing the star trails with so many subs. Hope you like it.

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/catalina071814.html

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Sat, 19 Jul 2014 17:45:58 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2014 E2  July 19
Excellent! I LOVE anti tails...

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

296P Garradd (tail : +/- 50")

C 2014 E2 Jacques, + G.R. (coma : +/- 6', ionic structure)

Date:  Mon, 28 Jul 2014 10:55:17 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2014 E2 July 26
Rolando, Erik
Dear comets friends

First, thank you for your interest in my images.
Comet Jaques is nice but not a second Lovejoy.
The fine details are lost in too short focal lengths and smaller aperture.
Perhaps the situation will be better if the comet comes closer to the earth.

Regards
Michael Jäger

From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2013 A1 (Siding Spring) - July 27th.
Hi all,

Here is C/2013 A1 captured yesterday. A rather odd looking comet at the moment with two almost opposing tails.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_a1_2014_07_27dp.jpg

17"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 16mins. RGB: 3mins

Damian

From:  michaeljaeger@gmx.at
Subject:  C/2014 E2 July 29
Hello

The comet is slowly higher. The tail structures are now more visible. Despite poor weather conditions, I found a dark and clear area to take this image

Jul. 29 UT 1.20 3x240 sec 8"/2.8 Sigma 6303 2x2 bin

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014E220140729bw_1406608584.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014E220140729bw_1406608584.jpg

July 30 UT 1.00 4x360sec
Newton 140/f-400 CCD Moravian G3-11002 1x1 bin

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014e220140730_1406698471.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014e220140730_1406698471.jpg

Michael Jäger 
Date:  Wed, 30 Jul 2014 08:19:47 -0700

July 30 UT 1.10

homemade Newton 140/f-400
CCD Moravian G3-11002

On the image the tail is >3°

http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014e220140730web2_1406733027.jpg http://spaceweathergallery.com/full_image.php?image_name=Michael-JAcger-2014e220140730web2_1406733027.jpg

Date:  Wed, 30 Jul 2014 20:41:29 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2013 A1 (Siding Spring) with Fornax A - July 28th.
Hi all,

Here is Comet Siding Spring passing by the peculiar radio galaxy
Fornax A - NGC1316 (4th brightest radio source in the sky.)

This proved to be a rather fascinating conjunction due to the strange appearance of this peculiar galaxy. The various faint shells surrounding it are
thought to have been caused by several galactic collisions in the remote past.

The image is also a great example of line of sight effect given the enormous difference in distance between comet and galaxy from us.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_a1_2014_07_28dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 24mins. RGB: 3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

*************************************************
Web: http://www.damianpeach.com/
FB: http://www.facebook.com/peachastro
Email: dpeach_78@yahoo.co.uk
*************************************************

Date:  Thu, 31 Jul 2014 08:08:30 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet C/2013 A1 (Siding Spring) with Fornax A - July 28th.
An excellent cometary conjunction image Damian! I was surprised to see how well the short RGB data was able to adequately colorize the stars. Fornax is getting above our horizon here in Arizona, but it is not easy. At least we have the race to mars to keep tabs on!

Clear Skies,

Chris

Hi all,

Here is Comet Siding Spring passing by the
peculiar radio galaxy
Fornax A - NGC1316 (4th brightest radio source in the
sky.)
This proved to be a rather
fascinating conjunction due to the strange appearance of
this peculiar galaxy. The various faint shells surrounding
it are
thought to have been caused by several galactic collisions
in the remote
past.

The image is also a
great example of line of sight effect given the enormous
difference in distance between comet and galaxy from us.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_a1_2014_07_28dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI camera.
LRGB. L: 24mins. RGB: 3mins.

Best Wishes

Damian

Date:  Sun, 03 Aug 2014 17:32:01 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Jacques imaging opportunities abound...
Greetings cometary friends. Sitting under raining skies for weeks, so I plotted out this comet for the next 50 days and oh my - its going to be traveling through some of the richest parts of our galaxy backgrounds. Here is a list of close conjunctions, many of them are direct pass overs.

Comet Jacques Imaging Opportunities 50 days - MST timezone

Aug 5 - Clusters Berk 12, 68
Aug 13 - NGC1491 nebula
Aug 14 - Sharpless 205 nebula
Aug 16 - King 6 open clust
Aug 18 - IC1871 the baby nebula
Aug 19 - IC1805 heart nebula
Aug 21 - Epsilon cass mag 3.3
Aug 23 - Sharpless 181 neb
Aug 26 - Sharpless 167 neb
Aug 28 - Sharpless 141 neb

Aug 30 - IC1396 Killer red neb!

Sept 2 - Berk 53 open clust
Sept 4 - sharpless 115 (deneb area)
Sept 6 - gamma cygni
Sept 9 - Sharpless 101 neb
Sept 17 - VDB 126 neb
Sept 19 - sharpless 83 neb

Into the Aquila / Scutum star clouds after that!

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Mon, 04 Aug 2014 11:25:41 +0200

Subject:  2014E2   2013A1  2013V5

/226_2014E2_0408.jpg

will be processed later:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/225_2013A1_0308.jpg

this morning:

http://www.astrostudio.at/2_Bright%20Comets.php?img=images/2_Bright%20Comets
/227_2013V5_0408.jpg

Gerald

UT 00.50
L4x400 2x2 bin
RGB 400/400/400 2x2 bin

Newton 140/400
Moravian G3-11002

Regards
Michael Jäger

Date:  Mon, 04 Aug 2014 15:23:48 +0200
From:  Michael Jaeger 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] 2014 E2 Aug.3  widefield tail>7°
Chris

The KAI 11002 is not particularly sensitive. Therefore, I prefer to work with 2x2 or 3x3 (or 4x4 for RGB)

REgards
Michael

----- Original Message -----
From: Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]
To: Comet-Images@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Monday, August 04, 2014 1:32 AM
Subject: Re: [Comet-Images] 2014 E2 Aug.3 widefield tail>7°

Micheal, good use of the 3x binning! For comets in particular where there is usually so little time before twilight interferes this is a great way to get a deep image. Nice job.

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com

Date:  Tue, 05 Aug 2014 22:55:22 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Jacques imaging opportunities abound...
Hi Chris,

A very hand list to have. I had noticed when checking this comet it passes many interesting objects in the weeks ahead. Lets hope it continues to maintain a nice appearance for a while longer yet. Michaels wide field images certainly show a fascinating and dynamic tail.

Best Wishes

Damian

________________________________
From: "Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images]"
To: Comet Group
Sent: Monday, 4 August 2014, 0:32
Subject: [Comet-Images] Comet Jacques imaging opportunities abound...

Greetings cometary friends. Sitting under raining skies for weeks, so I plotted out this comet for the next 50 days and oh my - its going to be traveling through some of the richest parts of our galaxy backgrounds. Here is a list of close conjunctions, many of them are direct pass overs.

Comet Jacques Imaging Opportunities 50 days - MST timezone

Aug 5 - Clusters Berk 12, 68
Aug 13 - NGC1491 nebula
Aug 14 - Sharpless 205 nebula
Aug 16 - King 6 open clust
Aug 18 - IC1871 the baby nebula
Aug 19 - IC1805 heart nebula
Aug 21 - Epsilon cass mag 3.3
Aug 23 - Sharpless 181 neb
Aug 26 - Sharpless 167 neb
Aug 28 - Sharpless 141 neb

Aug 30 - IC1396 Killer red neb!

Sept 2 - Berk 53 open clust
Sept 4 - sharpless 115 (deneb area)
Sept 6 - gamma cygni
Sept 9 - Sharpless 101 neb
Sept 17 - VDB 126 neb
Sept 19 - sharpless 83 neb

Into the Aquila / Scutum star clouds after that!

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Tue, 05 Aug 2014 15:21:52 -0700

Date:  Wed, 06 Aug 2014 18:09:06 +0200
From:  ligustri rolando 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] comet C/2014 E2 jaques this morning
Hi Michael,

You know very well that you and Gerald, I still consider the best photographers of
comets and then, for me, your compliments are worth double. However, the problems we
had to start working with this telescope, you have no idea, I tell you this only:

2 years ago we bought a FT focuser 3", last year we wanted to use the ASA 3"
corrector, but then, we discovered, to our cost, that the 3" of the FT were measured
outside! :(

we now use a 2.5" corrector but I'm afraid that for the our 50cm F3.3 is at the limit

regards
Rolando

From: "'Michael Jaeger' michaeljaeger@gmx.at [Comet-Images]"

Date:  Wed, 06 Aug 2014 12:06:49 -0700
From:  chergen@yahoo.com
Subject:  ALPO Comet Section Image Gallery
Hello Everyone,

The Association of Lunar and Planetary Observers (ALPO) invites you to contribute comet images, drawings, magnitude estimates, spectra and any other type of comet observations to their Comet Section. We are interested in both current and past comet observations.

Over the past few months, we have expanded the Comet Section website. Our goals are to encourage the observation of comets, act as a repository of comet data, and publish scientific articles on comets of interest.

ALPO Main Page - http://alpo-astronomy.org/ http://alpo-astronomy.org/
ALPO Comet Section Page - http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/cometblog/ http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/cometblog/
ALPO Comet Section Image Gallery - http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_itemId=4491 http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/gallery/main.php?g2_itemId=4491
ALPO Comet Magnitude Database (for current comets) - http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/cometblog/?page_id=237 http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/cometblog/?page_id=237
ALPO Comet Magnitude Database (for past comets) - http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/cometblog/?page_id=409 http://www.alpo-astronomy.org/cometblog/?page_id=409

Note, you do not have to be a member of the ALPO to contribute to any of its Sections as the ALPO webpages and image galleries are freely available to all users. Access to the quarterly "Journal of the ALPO", though, is an advantage of membership.

If you are interested, just drop me an email.

Thank you and happy observing!
- Carl Hergenrother

Coordinator, ALPO Comet Section

From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4 Catalina: 3 Aug. 2014
Gianluca, this is a perfect example on how many stars in the field could hide the extents of the tail easily. The delicate fan I see here would certainly be invisible without the median combine method. Nice Job!

Chris Schur

Date:  Wed, 06 Aug 2014 22:36:02 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Comet C/2013 V5 (Oukaimeden) - Aug 5th.
Hi all,

Here is my first image of this comet which promises to become a fine object in September. Its still low in the dawn sky at the moment but is already looking pretty good at around 10th mag.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_v5_2014_08_05dp.jpg

20"CDK with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 18mins. RGB: 3mins.

Date:  Thu, 07 Aug 2014 05:41:35 -0700
From:  Chris Schur 
Subject:  Comet Jacques C/2014  E2 - Finally a monsoon clearing!
Greetings cometary Friends,

The rains have stopped for a few days, and after a long planned shooting session yesterday morning, I will have the data to assemble a color 2 part panorama. While in process, I thought Id post the L channel from the first panel to show you. The number of stars in this part of Auriga is staggering! Over the next few days Ill be trying to tone them down a bit for the final two part that includeds 8 degrees of tail. Thanks for looking:

http://www.schursastrophotography.com/newcomets/Jacques080614a.html

PS - an interesting processing challenge on the panorma, the comets head is not in the second field and so when stacking, there is nothing to align on but stars...

Clear Skies,

Chris

Schur's Web Portal: http://www.schursastrophotography.com 

Date:  Thu, 07 Aug 2014 14:47:36 +0200
From:  Gianluca Masi 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] C/2013 UQ4 Catalina: 3 Aug. 2014
Hi Chris,

thank you for your comment and your appreciation.

I've found that this comet, because of its delicate aspect, was one of those
responding better to median combining among the ones I observed.

Wish you clear skies,
Gianluca

Il 06/08/2014 23:17, Chris Schur comets133@yahoo.com [Comet-Images] ha scritto:

> the extents of the tail easily. The delicate fan I see here would certainly be
> invisible without the median combine method. Nice Job!
>
> Clear Skies,

> Chris Schur

Hi
all,
Here
is my first image of this comet which promises to become a
fine object in September. Its still low in the dawn sky at
the moment but is already looking pretty good at around 10th
mag.

http://www.damianpeach.com/deepsky/c2013_v5_2014_08_05dp.jpg
20"CDK
with FLI camera. LRGB. L: 18mins. RGB: 3mins.
Best
Wishes
Damian

Date:  Thu, 07 Aug 2014 17:10:46 +0100
From:  Damian Peach 
Subject:  Re: [Comet-Images] Comet Jacques C/2014 E2 - Finally a monsoon clearing!
Very nice work Chris. The tail certainly looks decidedly wavy. Oukaimeden may prove a challenge given its rather poor solar elongation over the coming period. Its certainly looking promising at the moment....
